ImageMetaTag.webpage¶

Sub-module containing functions to write out an ImageDict to a webpage.

This can either be done using write_full_page, to produce a page with just a set of selectors to browse the ImageDict, or the different components can be added to a page as it is being constructed (reading in an html template, for instance).

To write out a full page, use ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_full_page().

If the latter, then the following sections are needed:

ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_js_setup() - writes out the scripting required on a page ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_js() - writes out the contents of the ImageDict as a javascript array ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_js_placeholders() - writes out the placeholders that thje javascript will write images to.

TODO: set up the dojo scripts/resources in a section for template type files

Warning

The Javascript code written by these routines works well up to ~250,000 to 500,000 images, depending on the ImageDict branching. Pages larger than this can be quite slow, and the Javascript needs refactoring to cope with this.

Writing a whole page¶

ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_full_page(img_dict, filepath, page_longname, page_filename=None, tab_s_name=None, preamble=None, postamble=None, verbose=False, internal=False, initial_selectors=None, url_type='int', only_show_rel_url=False)[source]¶

Writes out an ImageDict as a webpage, to a given filepath. The file is overwritten.

Currently only able to write out a page with horizontal dropdown menus, but other webpage styles could be added.

Options:
verbose: If True, stdout will be more verbose internal: If True, internal copies of the dojo Javascript API and css files will be used. only_show_rel_url: If True, the wepage will only show relative urls in is link section. initial_selectors: A list of initial values for the selectors, to be passed into write_js_setup

As indidividual components¶

ImageMetaTag.webpage.write_js_placeholders(file_obj=None, dict_depth=None, selector_prefix=None, style='horiz dropdowns')[source]¶

write the final details (which is the stuff that actually gets read!) at the end of a tab containing stdout stuff to a file object
